Markdown to Evernote, Slightly Modified

Jan 21, 2014
3 minute read

I recently started liking Markdown. I had no reason to like it – nothing was prompting me to like it. Over time, however, I began to love the elegant simplicity it offers.

One problem, however: my note-taking best friend Evernote doesn’t support Markdown; it only supports rich text. The dream of somehow accommodating Markdown into my life seemed to die a fiery death.

Wrong. If there’s one thing I can say about myself, it’s that such a conundrum serves only to motivate me (in an obsessive, stop-everything-until-I figure-it-out manner).

I took a quick stock of my assets:

  • Evernote
  • Textmate 2 (my long-loved programming text editor which, incidentally, supports Markdown)
  • Google

I began to assemble an idea: What if I hammered out quick text notes in Textmate 2 (to get the benefits of Markdown) and found a way to send the results to Evernote?

TL;DR

A quick tweak allows the sending of markdown “checkboxes” to Evernote as Evernote checkboxes.

The Setup

A quick Google search landed me on this blog post by Tim Lockridge. In it, Tim describes a great Textmate bundle action that sends the current document – as Markdown – to Evernote. It’s a great action that does it’s job well.

When I stress tested it, however, I came across something interesting – sending this Markdown from Textmate:

…produced this Evernote note:

I had expected the action to turn that [ ] into an Evernote checkbox. Given my propensity for using checkboxes in Evernote, I needed to fix that.

The Short Version

Here’s my modified bundle:

This bundle will correctly send <en-todo/> as a checkbox that Evernote can interpret. For example, this Markdown:

…produces this Evernote note:

The Long Version (in case you’re curious)

I dug into the action a bit and found this line of Ruby:

osa_cmd = "tell application #{quote 'Evernote'} to create note with html #{quote escape contents}"

Noticing the reference to html, I figured that sending the HTML equivalent of an Evernote checkbox:

…would suffice.

Well shucks – that’s not helpful.

I dug further into in the Evernote Applescript Dictionary and found that in addition to an HTML Content property, each Evernote note has an ENML Content property:

ENML content (text, r/o) : The note’s content in ENML representation.

What in the world is ENML?, I thought. More digging led to this definition on the Evernote Developer Portal:

ENML is the markup language used by Evernote to represent the content of notes. Because ENML is a superset of XHTML, it’s easy to present rich content in Evernote notes.

More playing with Applescript revealed the ENML definition of a checkbox (which, thank goodness, is much simpler):

<en-todo/>

Bingo. All that remained was to change the reference to HTML in the Ruby script (line 110, to be exact) to reference ENML:

wsa_cmd = "tell application #{quote 'Evernote'} to create note with enml #{quote escape contents}"

Final Thoughts

Obviously, typing out <en-todo/> all the time is a hassle. I recommend using a good text expander – such as my personal favorite, aText – to speed up the process. In my case, any time I type ,ent (for Evernote Todo), I get my magic ENML.

In the long run, we’ll see if this method of taking quick text notes remains a part of my toolkit. For now, I’ll chalk this up to an enjoyable exercise – one that hopefully provides value to others!
